thread.title: Treasury Futures Surge With Aussie Bonds After Greece ‘No’ Vote
thread.title_full: Treasury Futures Surge With Aussie Bonds After Greece ‘No’ Vote - Bloomberg Business

author: Garfield Clinton Reynolds
title: Treasury Futures Surge With Aussie Bonds After Greece ‘No’ Vote
text:
Treasuries futures surged along with Aussie bonds as concern Greece will exit the euro and trigger contagion across Europe bolstered demand for the safest securities.
Contracts for benchmark 10-year U.S. notes rose to the highest since June 1 and Australian 10-year yields slid to a one-week low. With 97 percent of votes counted, 61 percent of voters backed Prime Minister Alexis Tsipras and his Coalition of the Radical Left, or Syriza, by voting “no” to the latest proposals for spending cuts and tax increases.
JPMorgan Chase & Co. and Barclays Plc made a Greek departure from Europe’s monetary union their base scenario after the vote. JPMorgan said German 10-year yields may drop to 0.65 percent or less when bunds open on Monday, from 0.79 percent Friday. The turmoil may reduce the prospects for a Federal Reserve interest-rate increase in September, according to BNP Paribas SA.
“The Fed’s concerns about the possible impact of a Fed hike on markets and therefore on the economy will have intensified,” analysts led by Paul Mortimer-Lee, chief economist for North America at the French lender’s New York office, wrote in a note to clients. “It is unlikely that there will be sufficiently smooth waters in Europe for the Fed to tee up a September hike at its late July meeting.”
Ten-year Treasury futures for September delivery rose as much 1 10/32 to 127 6/32, before trading at 126 30/32 as of 7:50 a.m. Tokyo time.
Similar-dated Australian bonds climbed, sending the yield down 17 basis points to 2.90 percent. The yield on three-year Aussie debt dropped 14 basis points to 1.92 percent.
